I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Maldives (the Government) has requested the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building for the National Statistical 
System.1 The TA is in line with ADB's strategic focus under its country strategy and program 
(2002–2004), with the aim to strengthen the Government's institutional capacity for public sector 
management and policy planning, and has been in ADB's  assistance pipeline.2 The Fact-
Finding Mission from ADB visited the Maldives from 23 to 27 February 2003. The Mission 
reached an understanding with the Government on the justification and priority for the TA, its 
purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost and financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference for the TA consultants. The TA framework is given in Appendix 1.  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Economic and social statistics are the basic requirements for monitoring any country's 
development progress and formulating economic and social development policies and programs. 
The Maldives has made significant progress in improving the coverage and quality of economic 
and social statistics. However, many challenges remain. Due partly to the Maldives' dispersed 
geographical setting, the Government has a very decentralized statistics system: each line 
ministry collects and analyzes concerned data according to its own methodology, frequency, 
and quality control measures. This has led to a significant divergence in the concept and quality 
of data and inconsistency and incomparability of the data.   
 
3.  Due to its narrow industrial base and dependence on the external sector, the Maldives' 
economy is vulnerable to external developments. The Maldives is particularly influenced by the 
impact of global economic trends and the security situation in neighboring regions on tourism 
and the development of international tuna prices. The fragility of the economy accentuates the 
need for enhancing the country's  capacity to monitor its economic performance in a timely 
manner and thus to develop immediate policy responses. This will be especially important if the 
Maldives graduates from the least developed country status.  
 
4.  ADB and the Government entered into a poverty partnership agreement (PPA) in March 
2002. In line with the Millenium Development Goals, the PPA defines a long-term vision and 
sets out short-, medium-, and long-term priorities and targets in various aspects of poverty, i.e., 
income poverty, human poverty, and macroeconomic and sectoral development. To effectively 
implement the PPA, the Maldives needs to enhance its capacity to monitor its progress in 
achieving the priorities and targets. 
 
5.  Within the Government, the Statistics Section of the Ministry of Planning and National 
Development (MPND) is the focal point of national statistics. However, the decentralized system 
has hampered MPND's efforts to consolidate and integrate data and analyze them for policy 
feedback in a satisfactory manner. The Statistics Section has had insufficient cooperation from 
other ministries and the private sector, as there is concern about the independence of the 
Statistics Section and the mechanism to ensure the proper confidential use of the data provided.  
 
 
 
                                                 
1   The TA was formerly called as Establishment of Department/Bureau of Statistics.  
2   The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 20 January 2003.

2 
6.  Currently, the Maldives has no law to guide the Government's statistical activities. It has 
only statistical rules and regulations. The absence of the proper legal framework is a key 
constraint on the Statistics Section's ability to undertake statistical exercises, because there is 
no legal mechanism to ensure, and enforce as necessary,  cooperation from the relevant 
ministries, agencies, and private sector entities. The concern on  confidentiality  is a major 
setback of the absence of the appropriate legal framework. 
 
7.  ADB has provided two TAs to develop the Maldives' national accounts system.3 The TAs 
focused primarily on developing the methodology for gross domestic product (GDP) statistics. 
These TAs were satisfactorily  implemented and  resulted in significant improvements  in the 
quality of GDP statistics. However, key challenges (paras. 5–6) identified under the TAs are yet 
to be addressed, as these were beyond the scope of the TAs. 
 
8.  A key lesson learned from the previous TAs indicates the need for continued support for 
human resource development. Human capacity in the Statistics Section is still weak despite the 
training provided under the TAs, because (i) staff are not equipped with basic statistics skills or 
understanding in economics or relevant fields, due mainly  to the unavailability of in-country 
training opportunities in these areas; and (ii) the training provided was  confined to specific 
technical  aspects.  The  benefits  of  assistance  will  be  realized  only  if  a  mechanism  for 
sustainable and cost-effective in-house training is established. One approach will be training of 
trainers in the MPND. The trainers need to acquire both theoretical and technical knowledge of 
economics and statistics; this will be best undertaken by overseas studies and on-the-job-
training (OJT) because such opportunities are not available in the Maldives. At the same time, 
the  possibility  of  establishing  in-country  training  courses  in  the  Maldives'  postsecondary 
education institutions should be explored.  
 
9.  In  the  Maldives,  donor  agencies have made concerted efforts to build capacity for 
economic and social statistics. The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) has been 
active in poverty statistics. In 1998, UNDP helped the Government undertake a comprehensive 
poverty and  vulnerability survey in 1998 that covered all inhabited  islands and wide-ranging 
poverty and social statistics. This was the first nationwide survey on poverty, and proved to be 
an important exercise in understanding the poverty situation and formulating policy responses. 
To  further  strengthen  the  Government's  poverty  monitoring  capacity,  UNDP  is  currently 
providing  additional  assistance,  which  will  complement  ADB's  assistance  in  promoting 
institutional and legal development and enhancing technical capacity for economic and social 
statistics.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The purpose of the TA is to enhance the Government's institutional and human capacity 
in collecting, consolidating, and analyzing economic and social data. This will  enable the 
Government to develop more responsive and effective economic growth and poverty reduction 
policies and programs and to monitor the country's progress in achieving the goals and targets 
in the PPA and the Millenium Development Goals.  
                                                 
3  ADB. 1996.  Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Maldives for Development of a System of National 
Accounts, Manila; and ADB. 1998. Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Maldives for Further Development 
of a System of National Accounts. Manila.

3 
11.  The TA outputs will be (i)  establishment of an independent department of statistics 
supported with an appropriate legislative framework, including preparation of a statistics law for 
the department on the basis of the existing statistical rules and regulations; (ii) strengthening of 
the technical capacity for key economic and social statistics, particularly national accounts 
statistics; and (iii) upgrading of human resource in statistics required for the full functioning of 
the new department, through overseas studies and OJT and in-county seminars/workshops 
targeted at the concerned Government staff,  including those in the atolls. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The key activities of the TA will be (i) assistance to the Government in  institutional 
rearrangements and legal framework development; (ii) knowledge transfer regarding technical 
aspects of economic and social statistics; (iii) in-country and OJT training for MPND staff on the 
technical aspects of economic statistics; and (iv) overseas studies and OJT for selected staff 
aiming at a sustainable in-house training mechanism.  
 
13.  For the institutional and legal aspects, the TA will first develop a proposal for an 
independent department of statistics. Once the proposal has been finalized, the draft statistics 
law will be prepared on the basis of the existing statistical rules and regulations, and the 
statistical rules and regulations will be modified as necessary. For the statistics aspect, the TA 
will help upgrade statistics techniques and methodologies for surveys, price indexes, national 
accounts, and data processing. To enhance human resources, the TA will prepare a  human 
resource development plan, and staff will be provided with opportunities for overseas studies, 
OJT and in-county training. The courses of study will be selected in consultation with ADB. The 
TA will consider the  possibility of developing in-country diploma courses for economics and 
statistics with possible linkage with overseas accredited universities and  institutions. The TA 
activities will be based on the outcomes of the ADB's previous TAs.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $415,000 equivalent, comprising $354,000 of 
foreign exchange and $61,000 equivalent of local currency cost. ADB will finance $350,000 
equivalent to cover the foreign exchange cost of $343,000 and $7,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost, on a grant basis from ADB-funded TA program. The Government will fund the 
foreign exchange cost of $11,000 for overseas studies and OJT and the local currency cost of 
$54,000 equivalent for office accommodation, office equipment, counterpart staff, local transport, 
local workshops, and other logistical and administrative assistance. The cost estimates and 
financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Ministry of Finance and Treasury will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and 
MPND will be the  Implementing Agency. MPND will appoint an appropriate officer as project 
director, who will be responsible for the overall TA implementation. The Government's Statistical 
Coordination Committee, chaired by the deputy minister of MPND and attended by all the line 
ministries, will oversee TA implementation and resolve any issues related to policies, legislation, 
and interministerial cooperation and coordination. The Attorney General's Office will provide the 
necessary legal advice and assistance.

4 
16.  The TA will be carried out with the assistance of international consultants, who will be 
engaged for a total of 9 person-months. Selection and engagement of consultants from a 
consulting firm will be in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The 
international consultants will comprise a (i) statistical capacity  building specialist (3 person-
months) on institutional, legal, and human resource development aspects; (ii) survey and price 
index specialist (2 person-months), to improve surveys and price indexes; (iii) national accounts 
specialist  (2  person-months),  to  improve  the  national  accounts  statistics;  and  (iv)  data 
processing specialist (2 person-months), to enhance the automation system.  The outline terms 
of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
17.  The TA is expected to be implemented during a 1 year period, from July 2003 to June 
2004. The core activities that require the consultants' input will be carried out over a 6 month 
period, and the overseas studies and OJT will likely be for 1 year with  possible variations 
depending on the courses selected. The consultants will prepare an inception report within 15 
days of their starting work, and an interim report by 2 months from the commencement of their 
services. The consultants will submit the draft final report to the Government and ADB 3 weeks 
before the end of their assignment. The consultants will submit the final report incorporating 
comments from the Government and ADB within 3 weeks after receiving the comments. The 
Government will submit to ADB a supplementary report on the overseas studies and OJT. For 
each repot, five copies will be produced. The outline of the draft final report is in Appendix 4.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of  Maldives for Capacity Building for the National Statistical System, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be carried out based on the outcomes of previous 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  TAs.  The  consultants  are  required  to  (i)  review  all  the 
necessary documents, (ii) undertake the tasks with full consideration of the current system and 
methodologies, (iii) take the existing capacity of the local counterpart staff into full consideration 
in undertaking TA activities, and (iv) ensure technology transfer to the counterpart staff by the 
end of their services.  The consultants' work will be guided by the Government's Statistical 
Coordination Committee.  
 
  1.  Statistical Capacity Building Specialist and Team Leader (3 person-months)  
 
2.  The specialist will have had at least 10 years of experience in statistics-related projects, 
particularly in institutional and legal reforms and human resource planning, and will have skills 
as a team leader. His or her tasks and responsibilities under the TA will be to  
 
  (i)  take overall responsibility for proper and timely implementation of the TA;  
 
(ii)  assess the institutional and human resource capacity in the Ministry of Planning 
and National Development (MPND), other line ministries, and atoll and island 
offices; 
 
(iii)   develop  a  detailed  plan  for  a  department  of  statistics,  including  its  mission 
statement, organizational structure, and human resource allocation, and a time-
bound action plan toward its establishment;  
 
(iv)  prepare a human resource development plan including overseas studies and on-
the-job training and local workshops; 
 
(v)  develop diploma curricula for statistics and explore the possibility of establishing 
in-county diploma courses linked to overseas universities/institutions; and 
 
(vi)  prepare a draft of statistics law on the basis of the existing statistical rules and 
regulations and revisions thereof as necessary, under the guidance of MPND 
and the Statistical Coordination  Committee and in consultation with Attorney 
General's Office.  
 
 
  2.  Survey and Price Index Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will have had at least 5 years of experience in survey and price index 
methods. His or her tasks and responsibilities will be to 
 
(i)  assist  MPND  in  raising  data  collected  from  the  Household  Incomes  and 
Expenditures Survey (HIES) 2002/03 and Establishments Survey 2002/03;  
 
(ii)  assist MPND in preparing  surveys required to capture the value addition of 
selected economic activities;

Appendix 3  9 
(iii)  help complete the work on producer-production price index and unit value index, 
which started under a previous ADB TA, and prepare the work for publication; 
 
(iv)  assist MPND to compile consumer price index (CPI) basket and weights for Male' 
and other regions based on the HIES 2002/03; and 
 
(v)  train MPND staff on surveys and price indexes methodologies.  
 
 
  3.  National Accounts Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will have had at least 5 years of experience in capacity building for 
national accounts statistics. His or her tasks and responsibilities will be to 
 
  (i)  improve the quality of the national accounts, including development of quarterly 
national  accounts,  derivation  of  current  price  estimates,  and  integration  of 
financial and balance-of-payments statistics into the national accounts; and  
 
  (ii)  train MPND staff on national accounts statistics.  
 
 
4.  Data Processing Specialist (2 person-month) 
 
5.  The specialist will have had at least 5 years of experience in developing automation 
system in statistics. His/her tasks and responsibilities will be to 
 
(i)  assist in programming of surveys conducted  by MPND and train  staff in  the 
Delphi programming language;  
 
(ii)  design a database management system for the existing data file and train staff in 
database management; and  
 
(iii)  assist in programming the CPI, including the new regions, using the system 
designed for producer-production price index under the previous ADB TA.

10  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE OF THE FINAL REPORT 
 
A.  Institutional and Legal Aspect 
1.  This section will contain a 
 
  (i)  review of the existing institutional arrangements of the Government; 
 
  (ii)  proposal for an independent department of Statistics, with  mission statement, 
organizational structure and mandates, and human resource allocation; 
 
  (iii)  time bound action plan to establish the department of Statistics; 
 
  (iv)  proposed mechanism to enhance interministerial work on statistics; 
 
  (v)  review of the existing legal framework of the statistical rules and regulations and 
recommendations for improving the framework; and  
 
  (vi)  draft of statistics law and revised statistical rules and regulations.  
 
B.  Human Resource Development Aspect  
 
2.  This section will contain a  
 
(i)  review of the human resource capacity of the  Government and proposal for a 
program which will improve the situation in the most effective manner; 
 
(ii)  proposal for a human resource development program, focusing on (a) overseas 
studies and on-the-job training under the technical assistance (TA), (b) in-country 
training and workshops under the TA, and (c) recommendations for future human 
resource development programs; and 
 
(iii)  proposal  for  establishing  (a)  in-country  study  and  training  courses,  possibly 
linked  to  overseas  universities/institutions,  and  (b)  an  in-house  training 
mechanism  in  the  Statistics  Section  of  Ministry  of  Planning  and  National 
Development and, when established, the department of statistics. 
 
C.  Statistical Development Aspect 
 
3.  This section will contain 
 
(i)  a review of the statistical and methodological quality of key economic data, 
particularly national accounts, the consumer price index, and household and 
establishment surveys; 
 
(ii)  a summary of the work done to improve the key economic indicators; 
 
(iii)    a summary of the work done to ensure proper knowledge and skills transfer to 
the Government; and  
   
(iv)  an assessment of the need for future work.
